page.title: 5.11.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will study the successive bounce heights of balls, model the relationship between the number of bounces and the bounce heights, and use that model to answer questions about the balls’ bounciness. As you compare and critique the different models, you construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others. Technology isn’t required for this lesson, but there are opportunities for you to choose to use appropriate technology to solve problems. 

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:  

  • Use exponential functions to model situations that involve exponential growth or decay.
  • Determine an appropriate model for a situation described by data.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 5.11.1: Changing the Graphing Window
  • 5.11.2: Choosing an Appropriate Model
    • 5.11.2: Self Check 
  • 5.11.3: (Optional) Modeling with Exponential Functions
  • 5.11.4: Examine Exponential Decay in Context
    • 5.11.4: Self Check 
  • 5.11.5: Using Relationship Models to Answer Questions

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 5.11.6: Practice
  • 5.11.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 5.11.1: Changing the Graphing Window
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Here is a graph of a function \(f(x)=400 \cdot (0.2)^x\).

  1. Identify the approximate graphing window shown.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(0<x<44\) and \(0<y<1,100\) or equivalent



  1. Suggest a new graphing window that would:
    1. make the graph more informative or meaningful.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\( 0<x<10\) and \(0<y<450\). This window would include \(x\)-values where meaningful changes happen and exclude the parts where the changes are very small. The \(y\)-values are limited to values that matter, between 0 and 400, allowing us to see more clearly the changes in that range.



    1. make the graph less informative or meaningful.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(-10<x<80\) and \(10<y<700\). This window would show a lot of useless \(x\)-values and cut off the \(y\)-values at 100, which would hide the behavior of the function when \(x\) is between 0 and 1.

page.title: 5.11.2: Choosing an Appropriate Model
page.contents:
Activity

Here are measurements for the maximum height of a tennis ball after bouncing several times on a concrete surface.

\(n\)

bounce number

\(h\) 

height (centimeters)

0

150

1

80

2

43

3

20

4

11

  1. Which is more appropriate for modeling the maximum height \(h\), in centimeters, of the tennis ball after \(n\) bounces: A linear function or an exponential function? Use data from the table to support your answer.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.


Compare your answer:

Exponential. Sample explanations:

Plotting the points in the plane, they are not close to being on a line.

A linear function of the bounce height would decrease by the same amount for each successive bounce. The differences in heights between successive bounces are not close to being the same, as shown in the table. They are decreasing with each bounce, so the function is not linear.

bounce number

difference from height of previous bounce

0

--

1

70

2

37

3

23

4

9

An exponential function of the bounce height would decrease by the same factor for each successive bounce. It looks like each successive bounce is about half as high as the previous bounce, making an exponential model appropriate.

  1. Regulations say that a tennis ball, dropped on concrete, should rebound to a height between 53% and 58% of the height from which it is dropped. Does the tennis ball here meet this requirement? Explain your reasoning.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Yes. The first rebound is a little over 53%, the second is almost 54%, and the fourth is 55%. The third rebound is only about 47%, but there could be some measurement error.

No, the third rebound is less than 50% of the height from which the tennis ball fell, falling out of the allowable range.

It is not possible to tell. One of the values is too low, and the others are close enough to 53% that it is impossible to be sure whether the bounces of this ball fall within the regulations.


  1. Write an equation that models the bounce height \(h\) after \(n\) bounces for this tennis ball.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\( h=150 \cdot (0.53)^n\) (A factor of exactly 0.5 is also acceptable, or any value between 0.53 and 0.58.)


  1. About how many bounces will it take before the rebound height of the tennis ball is less than 1 centimeter? Explain your reasoning.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

8 bounces. Sample reasoning:

The height of the ball is decreasing by a factor of about \(\frac12\) after each bounce. So after 3 more bounces, it will decrease by a factor of about \(\frac18\) (giving a little more than 1 cm), but after 4 more bounces, it will decrease by a factor of about \(\frac{1}{16}\).

Graphing \( h=150 \cdot (0.53)^n\) and \(h=1\) simultaneously using graphing technology shows the bounce height first goes below \(h=1\) on the 8th bounce.


Video: Determining a Model and an Equation from a Real-World Scenario

Watch the following video to learn more about modeling exponential functions:

page.title: 5.11.2: Self Check
page.contents:
The table gives predictions of the average costs of a gasoline car after the year 2030.

Which graph best represents the relationship between time and the predicted cost?

Gasoline car

Time (years)

Cost (thousand of dollars)

0

35

5

40.2

10

46.3

15

53.2

20

61.2

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This graph shows a linear model. The table represents an exponential relationship. The answer is
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This graph shows a decreasing linear relationship. The numbers in the table are growing in a nonlinear and increasing way. The answer is
That’s correct! Check yourself: The cost of the car increases at an increasing rate over time.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This graph shows a decreasing relationship. The cost of the car increases over time. The answer is

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.11.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using an Exponential Model

A lab researcher records the growth of the population of a yeast colony and finds that the population doubles every hour. The table below records the first four hours.

Hours into study

0

1

2

3

4

Yeast colony population (thousands)

5

10

20

40

80

The starting value is 5 (in thousands) and the population doubles, so the growth factor is 2. 

The equation to model this growth is \(P(t)=5 \cdot 2^t\).

The graph is below:

Try It: Using an Exponential Model

A ball bounces up and down from a starting height of 65 centimeters. As it bounces, its height decreases to \(\frac13\) the previous height. Complete a table to represent the first 4 bounces. Then write a function, \(h(x)\), to determine the height after \(x\) bounces.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to find the model for this situation:

Number of bounces, \(x\)

0

1

2

3

4

Height, \(h(x)\)

65

\(\frac{65}{3}\)

\(\frac{65}{9}\)

\(\frac{65}{27}\)

\(\frac{65}{81}\)

The initial height is 65, and the growth factor is \(\frac13\).

The maximum height, \(h(x)\), after \(x\) bounces can be represented by \(h(x)=65 (\frac{1}{3})^x\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.11.3: (Optional) Modeling with Exponential Functions
page.contents:
Optional Activity

Your teacher will give your group three different kinds of balls.

Your goal is to measure the rebound heights, model the relationship between the number of bounces and the heights, and compare the bounciness of the balls.

  1. Complete the table. Make sure to note which ball goes with which column.

\(n\), number of bounces

\(a\), height for ball 1 (cm)

\(b\), height for ball 2 (cm)

\(c\), height for ball 3 (cm)

0

1

2

3

4

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

\(n\), number of bounces

\(a\), height for ball 1 (cm)

\(b\), height for ball 2 (cm)

\(c\), height for ball 3 (cm)

0

150

150

150

1

80

100

60

2

41

70

25

3

20

50

13

4

11

35

6


  1. Which one appears to be the bounciest? Which one appears to be the least bouncy? Explain your reasoning.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

The second ball is the bounciest. The balls were all dropped from the same height, and its bounces are the highest. The third ball is the least bouncy.


  1. For each one, write an equation expressing the bounce height in terms of the bounce number \(n\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

  • Ball 1: \(a=150 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^n\) or \(a=150 \cdot (0.5)^n\)
  • Ball 2: \(b=150 \cdot (\frac{7}{10})^n\) or \(b=150 \cdot (0.7)^n\)
  • Ball 3: \(c=150 \cdot (\frac{2}{5})^n\) or \(c=150 (0.4)^n\)

  1. Explain how the equations could tell us which one is the most bouncy.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

The bounciness of the ball is measured by the rebound factor, which is the base of the exponential expression. That is \(\frac12\) for the first ball, \(\frac{7}{10}\) for the second ball, and \(\frac25\) for the third ball. The larger this number, the bouncier the ball.

 


  1. If the bounciest one were dropped from a height of 300 cm, what equation would model its bounce height \(h\)?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(h=300 \cdot (\frac{7}{10})^n\)


Extending Your Thinking

  1. If Ball 1 were dropped from a point that is twice as high, would its bounciness be greater, less, or the same? Explain your reasoning.
  2. Ball 4 is half as bouncy as the least bouncy ball. What equation would describe its height \(h\) in terms of the number of bounces \(n\)?
  3. Ball 5 was dropped from a height of 150 centimeters. It bounced up very slightly once or twice and then began rolling. How would you describe its rebound factor? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  1. The same. The bounciness of the ball does not depend on the height from which it is dropped. This is why the successive rebound heights are modeled by an exponential function.
  2. \(h=150(\frac{1}{5})^n\)
  3. The rebound factor is very close to 0. Because the ball barely left the ground after hitting it, we could say that it lost almost all of its height with each bounce.

page.title: 5.11.4: Self Check
page.contents: The population of deer in a forest is divided in half every decade. Which of the following graphs could represent this situation?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This graph shows an increasing linear model. The population is decreasing in a nonlinear way. The answer is
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This graph shows a decreasing linear relationship. The population is decreasing in a nonlinear way. The answer is
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This shows an increasing relationship. The population is decreasing by a factor of \(\frac12\). The answer is
That’s correct! Check yourself: The population of deer will decrease over time, but the rate at which it decreases will slow down.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.11.4: Examine Exponential Decay in Context
page.contents:
Activity

The table shows some heights of a ball after a certain number of bounces.

bounce number

height in centimeters

0

1

2

73.5

3

51.5

4

36


  1. Is this ball more or less bouncy than the tennis ball in activity 5.11.2, which has the equation \(h=150 \cdot (0.53)^n\)? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

This ball is more bouncy. Each bounce of this ball reaches a height that is about 0.7 times that of the previous bounce \((51.5 \div 73.5 \approx 0.7)\). The tennis ball in the earlier task loses about half of its height with each bounce.



  1. From what height was the ball dropped? Explain or show your reasoning. Remember your units!

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

150 centimeters; \(73.5 \div 0.7=105\) and \(105 \div 0.7=150\).



  1. Write an equation that represents the bounce height of the ball, \(h\), in centimeters after \(n\) bounces.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(9h=150 \cdot (0.7)^n\)



  1. Which graph would more appropriately represent the equation for \(h\): Graph A or Graph B? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Graph B is more appropriate. Only whole-number \(n\) values make sense in this context. We cannot have bounce number 3.4, for example.



  1. Will the nth bounce of this ball be lower than the nth bounce of the tennis ball with equation \(h=150⋅(0.53)^n\)? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, the height of this ball after any given bounce will not be lower than that of the tennis ball because they were dropped from the same height and this ball has a greater rebound factor, so it will always bounce up to a higher point than the tennis ball.

page.title: 5.11.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Writing Exponential Decay Functions

A car sells for $4,000 and loses \(\frac18\) of its value each year. Write a function that gives the car’s value, \(V(t)\), \(t\) years after it is sold. 

Since the car loses \(\frac18\) of its value each year, it keeps \(\frac78\) of its value from year to year, so the growth factor is \(\frac78\).

\(V(t)=4000 \cdot (\frac{7}{8})^t\)

Try It: Writing Exponential Decay Functions

A computer is purchased for $1,000 and loses \(\frac15\) of its value per year.

Write a function for the computer’s value, \(V(t)\), \(t\) years after it is purchased.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to write the exponential function: 

The starting amount is $1,000. The computer loses \(\frac15\) of its value each year, so it maintains \(\frac45\) of its value. The growth factor is \(\frac45\).

The function is then \(V(t)=1000 \cdot (\frac{4}{5})^t\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.11.5: Using Relationship Models to Answer Questions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A ball is dropped from a certain height. The table shows the rebound heights of the ball after a series of bounces.

bounce number

height in centimeters

1

30

2

6

3

1

4

0

From what height, approximately, do you think the ball was dropped? Explain your reasoning.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Between 150 cm and 180 cm. The rebound factors are \(\frac15\), \(\frac16\), and 0 (this last measurement is probably not reliable because it could have been a very small bounce height, which would be difficult to measure). Because \(\frac15\) of 150 is 30 and \(\frac16\) of 180 is 30, the ball was probably dropped from between 150 cm and 180 cm.

page.title: 5.11.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–4, use the following:

Function \(h\) describes the height of a ball, in inches, after \(n\) bounces and is defined by the equation \(h(n)=120 \cdot (\frac{4}{5})^n\).

  1. What is \(h(3)\)? Round to the nearest integer. Think about what it represents in this situation.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 5.11.2–5.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 61. After 3 bounces, the bounce height is about 61 inches. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Could \(h(n)\) be 150?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 5.11.2–5.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is no. The ball is dropped from 120 inches, when \(n=0\), and decreases for each bounce after that. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which ball loses its height more quickly, this ball, modeled by \(h(n)=120 \cdot (\frac{4}{5})^n\), or a tennis ball whose height in inches after \(n\) bounces is modeled by the function \(f\) where \(f(n)=50 \cdot (\frac{5}{9})^n\)?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 5.11.2–5.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the ball modeled by \(f(n)\). The ball modeled by \(f(n)\) loses height more quickly because the bounce factor is \(\frac59\), which is less than \(\frac45\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. How many bounces would it take before the ball bounces less than 12 inches from the surface?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 5.11.2–5.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 11. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. After a second bounce, a ball reached a height of 70 cm. The rebound factor for the ball was 0.8. From approximately what height, in cm, was the ball dropped?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 5.11.4–5.11.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 88. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Using the table below, find the height, in cm, at which the ball was dropped.

Number of bounces

1

2

3

4

Height in cm

90

54

32

19

Enter your answer here. Enter Only Integers.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 5.11.4–5.11.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 150. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 5.11.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Use exponential functions to model situations that involve exponential growth or decay.
  • Determine an appropriate model for a situation described by data.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 5.11.1: Changing the Graphing Window
    • In this activity, you thought about how changing the graphing window influences what you can see and understand about an exponential function
  • 5.11.2: Choosing an Appropriate Model
    • In this activity, you examined the successive heights that a tennis ball reached after several bounces on a hard surface and considered how to model the relationship between the number of bounces and the height of the rebound. To do so, you determined the growth factor of successive bounce heights.  
  • 5.11.2: Self Check 
  • 5.11.3: (Optional) Modeling with Exponential Functions
    • In this activity, you had an opportunity to gather and analyze data for bounce heights for multiple balls. You processed your data and decided on an appropriate factor to quantify the bounciness of each ball. You became more  comfortable with the fact that the data are not exactly exponential and with choosing different ways for deciding on an appropriate exponential decay factor.
  • 5.11.3: Self Check 
  • 5.11.4: Examine Exponential Decay in Context
    • In this activity, you continued to examine exponential decay in the context of successive ball bounces. You used the given data to calculate a rebound factor and used it to write a function that models the relationship between number of bounces and bounce heights. You then used the function to answer questions about the ball and its bounces.
  • 5.11.4: Self Check 
  • 5.11.5: Using Relationship Models to Answer Questions
    • In this activity, you used data to determine from what height, approximately, you thought a ball was dropped and were able to explain your reasoning. 

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 5.11.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
